name: Pickled Mustard Greens Fried Rice (Takana Chahan)
description: This Pickled Mustard Greens Fried Rice—known as Takana Chahan—is a popular regional dish from Kyushu. Thanks to the tangy pickle, this simple fried rice is packed with comfort and plenty of umami! Add fluffy scrambled egg for extra protein and a pop of color. It‘s a quick meal you can make in 20 minutes.

video.name: Pickled Mustard Greens Fried Rice (Takana Chahan) 高菜チャーハン
video.description:
This Pickled Mustard Greens Fried Rice—known as Takana Chahan—is a popular regional dish from Kyushu. Thanks to the tangy pickle, this simple fried rice is packed with comfort and plenty of umami! Add fluffy scrambled egg for extra protein and a pop of color. It’s a quick meal you can make in 20 minutes.

RECIPE: https://www.justonecookbook.com/takana-chahan/

Ingredients:

2 servings cooked Japanese short-grain rice (cooled; day-old rice, preferably; if you haven't prepped the rice yet, cook 1½ rice cooker cups of short-grain rice and follow my instructions below on how to cool it)
1 Tokyo negi (naga negi; long green onion) (use only white bottom part; use the white bottom part of 3-4 scallions)
2 large eggs (50 g each w/o shell)
⅛ tsp kosher or sea salt (I use Diamond Crystal; use half for table salt) (for the eggs)
2 Tbsp neutral-flavored oil (vegetable, rice bran, canola, etc.)
1 Tbsp roasted sesame oil
1 package stir-fried takana (pickled mustard greens) (4.23 oz, 120 g; the package has the name takana aburaitame (高菜油炒め) or aji takana (味高菜); read more about this and how you can substitute in the blog post)
2 tsp soy sauce
¼ tsp kosher or sea salt (I use Diamond Crystal; use half for table salt)
⅛ tsp white pepper powder

recipeIngredient: 1  Tokyo negi (naga negi; long green onion)
2  large eggs (50 g each w/o shell)
⅛ tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt ((for the eggs))
¼ tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt

recipeInstructions.text: If you are using 2 servings of freshly cooked rice, transfer the hot rice to a baking sheet. Spread it out and let it cool completely.
recipeInstructions.name: If you are using 2 servings of freshly cooked rice, transfer the hot rice to a baking sheet. Spread it out and let it cool completely.

recipeInstructions.text: Cut and separate the white and green parts of 1 Tokyo negi (naga negi; long green onion) and set aside the green part for another use (I added it to miso soup with shiitake mushrooms). Thinly slice the white part of the negi.
recipeInstructions.name: Cut and separate the white and green parts of 1 Tokyo negi (naga negi; long green onion) and set aside the green part for another use (I added it to miso soup with shiitake mushrooms). Thinly slice the white part of the negi.

recipeInstructions.text: In a medium bowl, combine 2 large eggs (50 g each w/o shell) and ⅛ tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt and whisk together.
recipeInstructions.name: In a medium bowl, combine 2 large eggs (50 g each w/o shell) and ⅛ tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt and whisk together.

recipeInstructions.text: Heat 2 Tbsp neutral oil in a wok (I used this medium carbon steel wok) over medium heat. When the wok is hot, add the beaten eggs. After a few seconds, the egg will start to float on top of the oil.
recipeInstructions.name: Heat 2 Tbsp neutral oil in a wok (I used this medium carbon steel wok) over medium heat. When the wok is hot, add the beaten eggs. After a few seconds, the egg will start to float on top of the oil.

recipeInstructions.text: With a blunt-end wooden spatula, swirl the loosely set egg around the pan to continue cooking the rest of the egg.
recipeInstructions.name: With a blunt-end wooden spatula, swirl the loosely set egg around the pan to continue cooking the rest of the egg.

recipeInstructions.text: When the bottom of the egg is set but the top is not yet fully cooked, transfer it back to the bowl.
recipeInstructions.name: When the bottom of the egg is set but the top is not yet fully cooked, transfer it back to the bowl.

recipeInstructions.text: Add 1 Tbsp toasted sesame oil to the wok, then add the white part of the Tokyo negi. Stir-fry to coat with the oil.
recipeInstructions.name: Add 1 Tbsp toasted sesame oil to the wok, then add the white part of the Tokyo negi. Stir-fry to coat with the oil.

recipeInstructions.text: Add 1 package stir-fried takana (pickled mustard greens) and stir-fry for 2 minutes until well coated with oil.
recipeInstructions.name: Add 1 package stir-fried takana (pickled mustard greens) and stir-fry for 2 minutes until well coated with oil.

recipeInstructions.text: Add 2 servings cooked Japanese short-grain rice, cooled, to the wok. With the spatula, use a slicing motion to separate the rice clumps and combine the rice with the takana mixture.
recipeInstructions.name: Add 2 servings cooked Japanese short-grain rice, cooled, to the wok. With the spatula, use a slicing motion to separate the rice clumps and combine the rice with the takana mixture.

recipeInstructions.text: Season the fried rice with 2 tsp soy sauce, ¼ tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt, and ⅛ tsp white pepper powder. Taste the fried rice and adjust the seasoning since each brand of stir-fried takana is flavored differently.
recipeInstructions.name: Season the fried rice with 2 tsp soy sauce, ¼ tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt, and ⅛ tsp white pepper powder. Taste the fried rice and adjust the seasoning since each brand of stir-fried takana is flavored differently.

recipeInstructions.text: Add the cooked egg back into the wok and break it into smaller pieces. Toss everything together and turn off the heat. Serve the fried rice in individual plates/bowls. Enjoy!
recipeInstructions.name: Add the cooked egg back into the wok and break it into smaller pieces. Toss everything together and turn off the heat. Serve the fried rice in individual plates/bowls. Enjoy!

itemListElement.text: You can keep the leftovers in an airtight container and store in the refrigerator for up to 3 days and in the freezer for a month.
itemListElement.name: You can keep the leftovers in an airtight container and store in the refrigerator for up to 3 days and in the freezer for a month.

review.reviewBody: I just made this! I was the first time I ever made a fried rice recipe that turned out right! It tastes like the real thing too. Thanks so much Nami!

It was exactly perfect as written! I am lucky to live near a fantastic Japanese import store called Asahi imports in Austin, TX and they carry all of the wonderful things for these recipes! I used long grain rice since that was what I had on hand, and it came out perfectly flavored. Thank you for the recipes, keep them coming.

I adore this! It was so well timed: I have a jar of Chinese pickled greens I’m trying to use up. I followed your instructions for adjusting the flavor to be more like takana, and it came out great. I’ve made it twice already, and can’t wait to make it again. I’ll have to find some takana for the full experience!
